section.title: Building Systems
section.para: Running CentOS Studio gathers system content, processes it, and creates a complete solution.

section.title: Build Input
section.para: CentOS Studio uses three classes of input to create solutions: a base operating system, package repositories, and configuration files and scripts. System content is specified using a system definition.

itemizedlist.listitem: Base Operating System. CentOS Studio requires a base operating solution as input for creating new solutions. The base operating system is defined at the level of operating system name (Red Hat Enterprise Linux or CentOS), version (5) and architecture (i386 or x86_64). The four base operating systems CentOS Studio supports are RHEL-5-i386, RHEL-5-x86_64, CentOS-5-i386 and CentOS-5-x86_64. Base operating solutions must include both network installation images and package repositories. Base operating solutions are covered in more detail under .

Package Repositories. CentOS Studio uses RPM package repositories to locate and download software components for the solution. CentOS Studio requires at least one package repository, that of the base operating solution. A typical system definition will specify multiple input repositories, including the base operating system update repository, and repositories made available from other internal and external providers. See for more information.

Configuration Files and Scripts. The final category of solution content is user-provided configuration files and scripts. Files are copied, and scripts are executed, during client machine installation and updates. For more information, see .

section.title: Build Process
section.para: CentOS Studio uses information from the to gather solution content. It processes this information in three primary ways.

listitem.para: Creates a configuration package. CentOS Studio creates a in RPM format. This package contains configuration files and scripts specified in the solution definition. It also contains CentOS Studio-generated YUM update configuration. See for more information on CentOS Studio-generated YUM configuration.

During this step, CentOS Studio also creates a , if one does not exist, in the same folder as the solution definition. The file has a .dat extension. CentOS Studio uses the data file to track and increment the configuration package release number.

itemizedlist.listitem: Assembles a package repository. Using the solution definition, CentOS Studio compiles a list of required packages. It then resolves package dependencies, downloads packages, adds the configuration package (mentioned in the previous item) and creates a complete, self-contained package repository. The package repository is used during network installations to client machines. It is also used during client machine updates.

Customizes network install images. CentOS Studio downloads network installation images from the base operating system and modifies them to include system-specific information. By default, CentOS Studio configures the installer program contained within the images to access content from the solution's . This allows client machines to be installed over the network without needing to provide the download location manually at installation time. CentOS Studio can also be used to completely automate client installations. See for more information.

section.para: CentOS Studio stores system content, both input and generated, in the cache folder, by default /var/cache/centosstudio/. It reuses information from the cache on subsequent runs, where possible, to improve build performance.

section.title: Build Output
section.para: CentOS Studio outputs a complete solution, a solution data file and a log file.

itemizedlist.listitem: System. The primary output of the build process is a complete solution containing system-specific network installation images and a package repository. Using network installation images you can deploy the solution to one or more physical or virtual client machines. See for more information. The system package repository supports client machine updates using YUM. The section provides an overview of CentOS Studio's client machine update features.
System Data File. As mentioned above, CentOS Studio creates a during the build process. This file is used to track and increment the release number of the configuration package.
CentOS Studio Log File. CentOS Studio sends output both to the screen and to a log file, located by default at /var/log/centosstudio.log.

section.para: In summary, CentOS Studio is a production system life cycle manager for use in defining, building and maintaining solution that can be easily installed and updated on physical and virtual machines using industry standard deployment and update tools.
